unnormalised: Okay, so someone asked about the future of robotics in India? That’s a big question! I remember watching this Doordarshan show as a kid, maybe around '95 or '96, about robots doing everything. Felt like such a distant dream then.
normalised: Okay, so someone asked about the future of robotics in India? That is a big question! I remember watching this Doordarshan show as a kid, maybe around nineteen ninety five or nineteen ninety six, about robots doing everything. Felt like such a distant dream then.

unnormalised: Now, things are changing fast. I saw this article the other day, said that by 2030, India's robotics market will be worth $5 billion. Companies like DRDO are already doing some pretty cool stuff with robots for defence. Plus, you've got startups popping up in places like Bangalore and Chennai, building robots for agriculture, healthcare...even for cleaning solar panels! Think about that, solar panel cleaning bots…Rs. 2 lakhs a pop maybe?
normalised: Now, things are changing fast. I saw this article the other day, said that by two thousand and thirty, India's robotics market will be worth five billion dollars. Companies like D-R-D-O are already doing some pretty cool stuff with robots for defence. Plus, you have got startups popping up in places like Bangalore and Chennai, building robots for agriculture, healthcare...even for cleaning solar panels! Think about that, solar panel cleaning bots…rupees two lakhs a pop maybe?

unnormalised: The challenge, I think, is making robots that actually work in Indian conditions. Our roads are chaotic, our farms are different, our hospitals are... well, you get the idea. A robot designed for a factory in Germany isn't going to be much use in a textile mill in Surat. But that's also the opportunity, right? To build robots specifically for India, by Indians. IIT-Mumbai is doing great research in this field.
normalised: The challenge, I think, is making robots that actually work in Indian conditions. Our roads are chaotic, our farms are different, our hospitals are... well, you get the idea. A robot designed for a factory in Germany is not going to be much use in a textile mill in Surat. But that is also the opportunity, right? To build robots specifically for India, by Indians. I-I-T Mumbai is doing great research in this field.

unnormalised: Honestly, I think we're on the cusp of a robotics revolution. It won't be like in the movies – no C-3PO serving chai anytime soon! But robots will definitely be a bigger part of our lives, from helping doctors in AIIMS to assisting farmers in Punjab. I’m pretty sure my nephew, Aryan, who's studying engineering, will be part of that wave. Maybe he'll even build that chai-serving robot someday!
